question: It is true that the main objective of scheduling is to maximize CPU usage.
It is false that scheduling aims to maximize the number of processes completed per unit time.
It is true that CPU burst refers to the time a process is using the CPU for calculations.
It is false that I/O burst refers to a process using the CPU for calculations.
It is true that preemptive scheduling allows a process to be interrupted if a higher-priority task arrives.
It is false that non-preemptive scheduling allows the CPU to switch from one process to another before the current process completes.
It is true that round-robin scheduling is an example of a preemptive scheduling algorithm.
It is false that Shortest Job Next (SJN) is a preemptive scheduling algorithm.
It is true that First Come, First Served (FCFS) is an example of non-preemptive scheduling.
It is false that Priority Scheduling (Non-Preemptive) allows processes to be interrupted once started.
It is true that scheduling criteria include CPU utilization, throughput, turnaround time, waiting time, and response time.
It is false that throughput refers to the percentage of time the CPU is busy.
It is true that response time refers to the time from when a request is made until it starts execution.
It is false that turnaround time refers to the time a process spends waiting in the queue.
It is true that in preemptive scheduling, the CPU can switch from one process to another before the current process finishes.
It is false that non-preemptive scheduling allows processes to be interrupted once they start running.
It is true that preemptive scheduling ensures better resource allocation but may have more overhead.
It is false that non-preemptive scheduling is better for resource allocation but more complex.
It is true that the CPU should be kept busy as much as possible to maximize CPU usage.
It is false that scheduling ensures processes never have to wait.
It is true that fairness in scheduling ensures every process gets a fair chance to run.
It is false that scheduling guarantees a process will always finish quickly.
It is true that the main objective of non-preemptive scheduling is to minimize waiting times.
It is false that non-preemptive scheduling can sometimes cause long waiting times.
It is true that Shortest Remaining Time First (SRTF) schedules the process with the shortest remaining time first.
It is false that SRTF is a non-preemptive scheduling algorithm.
It is true that waiting time refers to the time a process spends in the queue waiting for the CPU.
It is false that response time refers to the total time taken for a process to complete.
It is true that turnaround time refers to the total time from when a process arrives until it finishes.
It is false that preemptive scheduling is simpler than non-preemptive scheduling.
It is true that priority scheduling (preemptive) switches to the highest priority task.
It is false that priority scheduling (non-preemptive) allows processes to be interrupted by higher priority tasks.
It is true that the CPU should be used efficiently in preemptive scheduling systems.
It is false that non-preemptive scheduling can lead to high CPU utilization.
It is true that a good scheduling algorithm balances CPU and I/O bursts effectively.
It is false that a good scheduling algorithm favors CPU bursts over I/O bursts.
It is true that a good scheduling algorithm helps minimize waiting time and turnaround time.
It is false that turnaround time includes only the time spent executing the process.
It is true that scheduling criteria aim to maximize system efficiency and fairness.
It is false that scheduling criteria only focus on CPU utilization and throughput.
It is true that preemptive scheduling may have higher overhead due to context switching.
It is false that non-preemptive scheduling does not require any context switching.
It is true that Shortest Job Next (SJN) is a non-preemptive scheduling algorithm.
It is false that Shortest Job Next (SJN) is a preemptive scheduling algorithm.
It is true that preemptive scheduling is often used when fairness is a priority.
It is false that non-preemptive scheduling is ideal for maximizing fairness.
It is true that response time is important for interactive systems where quick feedback is required.
It is false that response time is not an important factor for interactive systems.
It is true that the scheduling algorithm needs to balance between CPU utilization and fairness.
It is false that a good scheduling algorithm should prioritize CPU utilization over all other criteria.
